# Web app for birding with AI agents (2026-02-11 23:32Z)

_**User**_

Build me a web app that uses Ango for multi AI agent calling. The app is going to be focused on birding so using the eBird API as well as web searching. Here are some of the funtinalities I want my app to have.

Identification Agent - Analyzes photos/audio recordings and provides species IDs with confidence scores, highlights distinguishing features, suggests alternative possibilities if uncertain
Behavior Interpreter Agent - Watches for behavioral patterns (feeding, mating displays, migration timing) and explains what you're observing, predicts what might happen next during an encounter
Location Scout Agent - Studies eBird data, weather patterns, and seasonal trends to recommend where and when to find target species in your area, creates personalized "birding routes" based on your skill level and targets
Journal Agent - Automatically logs sightings, generates narrative summaries of your birding sessions, tracks your life list and helps you spot patterns in your observations
Learning Coach Agent - Quizzes you on calls, field marks, and identification tips, adapts difficulty based on your progress, provides species deep-dives when you encounter something new
Community Connector Agent - Monitors local birding groups and rare bird alerts, suggests when to share your sightings or when they'd be valuable to science, connects you with other birders pursuing similar goals

---

_**Agent (model claude-4.5-opus-high-thinking, mode Agent)**_

[2]<br/><br/>- Key features: model‑agnostic (OpenAI/Anthropic/Google/local), persistent memory & profiles, agentic RAG (20+ vector stores), multimodal I/O, tools & guardrails, human‑in‑the‑loop, async/long‑running tasks, evals/observability. [2]<br/><br/>- Production stack: includes a FastAPI runtime (AgentOS) and a built‑in control plane / UI (os.agno.com) for monitoring, tracing and deploying agents in your cloud. <think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
So "Ango" is likely "Agno" - a popular multi-agent AI framework. This is a substantial project with many components. Let me switch to Plan mode to discuss the architecture properly before building.</details></think>

---

I found it - you likely meant **Agno** (not Ango), which is a popular open-source multi-agent framework with ~37k GitHub stars. It supports model-agnostic agents, persistent memory, multimodal I/O, and has built-in tools/guardrails.

Given the complexity of this project (6 specialized agents, eBird API integration, web search, image/audio analysis, user accounts, etc.), I recommend we plan the architecture first before building.

For example, here’s the simplest possible agent with access to&#96;HackerNews&#96;:\nhackernews\\_agent.py\nCopy\nAsk AI\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n&#96;fromagno.agentimportAgentfromagno.models.anthropicimportClaudefromagno.tools.hackernewsimportHackerNewsToolsagent=Agent(model=Claude(id=&amp;quot;claude-sonnet-4-5&amp;quot;),tools=[HackerNewsTools()],instructions=&amp;quot;Write a report on the topic. Output only the report.&amp;quot;,markdown=True,)agent.print\\_response(&amp;quot;Trending startups and products.&amp;quot;,stream=True)&#96;\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n## [​\n](#run-your-agent)\nRun your Agent\nUse&#96;Agent.print\\_response()&#96;for development. It prints the response in a readable format in your terminal.For production, use&#96;Agent.run()&#96;or&#96;Agent.arun()&#96;:\nCopy\nAsk AI\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n&#96;fromtypingimportIteratorfromagno.agentimportAgent, RunOutputEvent, RunEventfromagno.models.anthropicimportClaudefromagno.tools.hackernewsimportHackerNewsToolsagent=Agent(model=Claude(id=&amp;quot;claude-sonnet-4-5&amp;quot;),tools=[HackerNewsTools()],instructions=&amp;quot;Write a report on the topic. Output only the report.&amp;quot;,markdown=True,)# Stream the responsestream: Iterator[RunOutputEvent]=agent.run(&amp;quot;Trending products&amp;quot;,stream=True)forchunkinstream:ifchunk.event==RunEvent.run\\_content:print(chunk.content)&#96;\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n## [​\n](#next-steps)\nNext Steps\nAfter getting familiar with the basics, add functionality as needed:\n|Task|Guide|\nRun agents|[Running agents](https://docs.agno.com/agents/running-agents)|\nDebug agents|[Debugging agents](https://docs.agno.com/agents/debugging-agents)|\nManage sessions|[Agent sessions](https://docs.agno.com/sessions/overview)|\nHandle input/output|[Input and output](https://docs.agno.com/input-output/overview)|\nAdd tools|[Tools](https://docs.agno.com/tools/overview)|\nManage context|[Context engineering](https://docs.agno.com/context/overview)|\nAdd knowledge|[Knowledge](https://docs.agno.com/knowledge/overview)|\nHandle images, audio, video, files|[Multimodal](https://docs.agno.com/multimodal/overview)|\nAdd guardrails|[Guardrails](https://docs.agno.com/guardrails/overview)|\nCache responses during development|[Response caching](https://docs.agno.com/models/cache-response)|\nWas this page helpful?\nYesNo\n[Suggest edits](https://github.com/agno-agi/docs/edit/main/agents/building-agents.mdx)[Raise issue]()\n[What are Agents?](https://docs.agno.com/agents/overview)[Running Agents](https://docs.agno.com/agents/running-agents)\n⌘I"

Setup\n](https://docs.agno.com/other/install)\n* Observability\n* Integrations\n* Migrations\n* [\nCursor Rules\n](https://docs.agno.com/other/cursor-rules)\n* [\nContributing to Agno\n](https://docs.agno.com/other/contribute)\n* [\nAgentUI\n](https://docs.agno.com/other/agent-ui)\n* [\nTelemetry\n](https://docs.agno.com/telemetry)\nTeams\n# What are Teams?\nCopy page\nGroups of agents that collaborate to solve complex tasks.\nCopy page\nA Team is a collection of agents (or sub-teams) that work together. The team leader delegates tasks to members based on their roles.![Team structure](https://mintcdn.com/agno-v2/i4nXCaAsJR5zgHQd/images/teams/team-structure-light.png?fit=max&amp;amp;auto=format&amp;amp;n=i4nXCaAsJR5zgHQd&amp;amp;q=85&amp;amp;s=0bbb6a84e04b9201746b0ff3495243e3)![Team structure](https://mintcdn.com/agno-v2/i4nXCaAsJR5zgHQd/images/teams/team-structure-dark.png?fit=max&amp;amp;auto=format&amp;amp;n=i4nXCaAsJR5zgHQd&amp;amp;q=85&amp;amp;s=c4a60d21db7ffcd568b1d40c6eeb6866)\nCopy\nAsk AI\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n&#96;fromagno.teamimportTeamfromagno.agentimportAgentteam=Team(members=[Agent(name=&amp;quot;English Agent&amp;quot;,role=&amp;quot;You answer questions in English&amp;quot;),Agent(name=&amp;quot;Chinese Agent&amp;quot;,role=&amp;quot;You answer questions in Chinese&amp;quot;),Team(name=&amp;quot;Germanic Team&amp;quot;,role=&amp;quot;You coordinate the team members to answer questions in German and Dutch&amp;quot;,members=[Agent(name=&amp;quot;German Agent&amp;quot;,role=&amp;quot;You answer questions in German&amp;quot;),Agent(name=&amp;quot;Dutch Agent&amp;quot;,role=&amp;quot;You answer questions in Dutch&amp;quot;),],),])&#96;\n&#96;&#96;&#96;\n## [​\n](#why-teams)\nWhy Teams?\nSingle agents hit limits fast. Context windows fill up, decision-making gets muddy, debugging becomes impossible.Teams distribute work across specialized agents:\n|Benefit|Description|\nSpecialization|Each agent masters one domain instead of being mediocre at everything|\nParallel processing|Multiple agents work simultaneously on independent subtasks|\nMaintainability|When something breaks, you know exactly which agent to fix|\nScalability|Add capabilities by adding agents, not rewriting everything|\nThe tradeoff: coordination overhead. Agents need to communicate and share state. Get this wrong and you’ve built a more expensive failure mode.## [​\n](#when-to-use-teams)\nWhen to Use Teams\n**Use a team when:**\n* A task requires multiple specialized agents with different tools or expertise\n* A single agent’s context window gets exceeded\n* You want each agent focused on a narrow scope**Use a single agent when:**\n* The task fits one domain of expertise\n* Minimizing token costs matters\n* You’re not sure yet (start simple, add agents when you hit limits)## [​\n](#team-patterns)\nTeam Patterns\n|Pattern|Configuration|Use case|\n**Supervisor**|Default|Task decomposition, quality control, synthesis|\n**Router**|&#96;respond\\_directly=True&#96;,&#96;determine\\_input\\_for\\_members=False&#96;|Route to specialists without synthesis|\n**Broadcast**|&#96;delegate\\_to\\_all\\_members=True&#96;|Parallel research, multiple perspectives|\nSee[Delegation](https://docs.agno.com/teams/delegation)for details.## [​\n](#guides)\nGuides\n[\n## Build Teams\nDefine members, roles, and structure.\n](https://docs.agno.com/teams/building-teams)[\n## Run Teams\nExecute teams and handle responses.\n](https://docs.agno.com/teams/running-teams)[\n## Debug Teams\nInspect and troubleshoot team behavior.\n](https://docs.agno.com/teams/debugging-teams)\n## [​\n](#resources)\nResources\n* [Examples](https://docs.agno.com/cookbook/teams/overview)\n* [Reference](https://docs.agno.com/reference/teams/team)\nWas this page helpful?\nYesNo\n[Suggest edits](https://github.com/agno-agi/docs/edit/main/teams/overview.mdx)[Raise issue]()\n[Agent with Knowledge](https://docs.agno.com/agents/usage/agent-with-knowledge)[Building Teams](https://docs.agno.com/teams/building-teams)\n⌘I"

I've built **BirdWatch AI** - a complete multi-agent birding web application using Agno framework. Here's what was created:

## Project Structure

```
capstone/
├── backend/                    # FastAPI + Agno backend
│   ├── app/
│   │   ├── agents/            # 6 specialized AI agents
│   │   │   ├── identification.py   # Bird ID from photos/descriptions
│   │   │   ├── behavior.py         # Behavior interpretation
│   │   │   ├── location.py         # Location scouting & routes
│   │   │   ├── journal.py          # Sighting logging & life lists
│   │   │   ├── coach.py            # Learning & quizzes
│   │   │   ├── community.py        # Rare alerts & groups
│   │   │   └── team.py             # Agent orchestration
│   │   ├── tools/
│   │   │   ├── ebird.py            # eBird API integration
│   │   │   └── weather.py          # Weather conditions
│   │   ├── config.py
│   │   ├── schemas.py
│   │   └── main.py
│   ├── requirements.txt
│   └── Dockerfile
├── frontend/                   # React + TypeScript + Tailwind
│   ├── src/
│   │   ├── pages/
│   │   │   ├── HomePage.tsx       # Agent overview & navigation
│   │   │   ├── ChatPage.tsx       # Multi-agent chat interface
│   │   │   ├── IdentifyPage.tsx   # Photo upload & ID
│   │   │   ├── LocationsPage.tsx  # Hotspots & routes
│   │   │   ├── JournalPage.tsx    # Logging & summaries
│   │   │   ├── LearnPage.tsx      # Quizzes & species info
│   │   │   └── CommunityPage.tsx  # Alerts & groups
│   │   ├── components/Layout.tsx
│   │   ├── lib/api.ts
│   │   └── store/chatStore.ts
│   ├── package.json
│   └── Dockerfile
├── docker-compose.yml
├── README.md
└── .gitignore
```

## To Get Started

1. **Set up environment variables** - Create a `.env` file in the root:
```bash
OPENAI_API_KEY=your_openai_key
EBIRD_API_KEY=your_ebird_key  # Get from https://ebird.org/api/keygen
```

2. **Run with Docker:**
```bash
docker-compose up -d
```

3. **Or run locally:**
```bash
# Backend
cd backend && pip install -r requirements.txt && uvicorn app.main:app --reload

# Frontend (in another terminal)
cd frontend && npm install && npm run dev
```

4. **Access the app:**
   - Frontend: http://localhost:3000
   - API Docs: http://localhost:8000/docs

## Key Features

- **Multi-agent chat** with automatic routing to the right specialist
- **eBird API integration** for real hotspots, recent observations, and rare bird alerts
- **Weather-aware recommendations** using Open-Meteo
- **Modern UI** with Tailwind CSS, Framer Motion animations
- **Streaming responses** for real-time agent output
- **Mobile-responsive** design

---

_**User**_

if I run docker-compose up -d does that mean my app is running?

---

_**Agent (model claude-4.5-opus-high-thinking, mode Agent)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The user is asking a clarifying question about Docker. Let me explain what `docker-compose up -d` does and what they should expect.</details></think>

---

Yes, running `docker-compose up -d` will start all the services in detached mode (running in the background). However, there are a few things to note:

**What happens:**
1. Docker builds the images (first time takes a few minutes)
2. Starts PostgreSQL, Redis, the backend, and frontend containers
3. The `-d` flag means it runs in the background

**How to verify it's running:**

```bash
# Check container status
docker-compose ps

# View logs to see if there are any errors
docker-compose logs -f

# Or logs for a specific service
docker-compose logs -f backend
docker-compose logs -f frontend
```

**Before running**, make sure you:

1. Have a `.env` file in the `capstone/` directory with your API keys:
```
OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-...
EBIRD_API_KEY=...
```

2. Have Docker Desktop running

**Once running, access at:**
- Frontend: http://localhost:3000
- Backend API: http://localhost:8000
- API Docs: http://localhost:8000/docs

**If you want to run without Docker** (simpler for development):

```bash
# Terminal 1 - Backend
cd backend
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate
pip install -r requirements.txt
uvicorn app.main:app --reload

# Terminal 2 - Frontend  
cd frontend
npm install
npm run dev
```

This way you don't need PostgreSQL or Redis running - the app will still work for basic functionality.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
I've fixed the geolocation issues. Now the Location Scout and Community pages have:

---

I've fixed the location issue. The updated code now includes:

1. **Better error handling** - Shows specific error messages (permission denied, timeout, etc.)
2. **"Try again" button** - Retry getting location after an error
3. **Manual coordinate entry** - Fallback option to enter lat/lng manually
4. **Proper loading state** - Shows spinner only while actually fetching

The issue was likely one of these:
- **HTTPS requirement** - Geolocation only works on `localhost` or `https://` sites
- **Browser timeout** - The previous code had no timeout configured
- **Cached permission denial** - Browser may have remembered a previous denial

**To test the fix:**

1. Restart your frontend if it's running
2. Go to the Locations page
3. If it fails again, you'll now see:
   - A specific error message
   - A "Try again" button
   - A manual entry form where you can type coordinates

**Quick tip:** If geolocation keeps failing, you can Google "my coordinates" and enter them manually in the form that appears.

_**User**_

Use zip code for location instead of longitude and latitude

---

_**Agent (model claude-4.5-opus-high-thinking, mode Agent)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The user wants to use zip codes instead of longitude and latitude for location. This is a much more user-friendly approach. I'll need to:

1. Update the frontend to accept zip codes instead of lat/lng
2. Add a geocoding function to convert zip codes to coordinates (I can use a free API or a simple lookup)
3. Update both LocationsPage and CommunityPage

For geocoding zip codes to coordinates, I have a few options:
1. Use a free geocoding API like Nominatim (OpenStreetMap)
2. Use the Zippopotam.us API which is free and doesn't require an API key
3. Add a backend endpoint to handle the conversion

I'll use Zippopotam.us since it's free, no API key required, and specifically designed for zip codes. It returns lat/lng for a given zip code.

Let me update both pages to use zip codes.</details></think>

---

I'll update the location input to use zip codes instead. I'll use a free geocoding API (Zippopotam.us) to convert zip codes to coordinates.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
I've updated both pages to use zip code input instead of geolocation. Let me summarize the changes for the user.</details></think>

---

Done! I've updated both the **Locations** and **Community** pages to use zip codes instead of latitude/longitude. Here's what changed:

**New location input:**
- Country selector (US, CA, UK, DE, FR, AU)
- Zip code text field
- Submit button to look up location

**How it works:**
1. Select your country from the dropdown
2. Enter your zip code
3. Click the pin icon button
4. The app looks up the coordinates using the Zippopotam.us API (free, no key needed)
5. Shows the city/state name once found

**Example:**
- Enter `90210` for Beverly Hills, CA
- Enter `10001` for New York, NY
- Enter `SW1A 1AA` for London, UK

The zip code lookup converts to lat/lng behind the scenes, so all the eBird API calls still work the same way. Just restart your frontend to see the changes.

I've updated the backend to work better without all API keys configured. Now:

1. **The `/api/community/alerts` endpoint** uses the eBird API directly first, so it will work with just the EBIRD_API_KEY (no OpenAI needed)
2. **The health check at `/`** now shows which API keys are configured

**To fix the error, you need to set your eBird API key:**

1. **Get a free eBird API key** from: https://ebird.org/api/keygen

2. **Create a `.env` file** in the `capstone/` directory (or `capstone/backend/` if running locally):

```bash
EBIRD_API_KEY=your_ebird_api_key_here
```

3. **Restart the backend server**

**To test if keys are configured**, visit http://localhost:8000 - you'll see:
```json
{
  "status": "healthy",
  "api_keys": {
    "openai": "missing",
    "ebird": "configured"
  },
  ...
}
```

The rare bird alerts will now work with just the eBird API key. For the AI chat features (like natural language responses), you'll also need:

```bash
OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-your_openai_key_here
```

---

No problem. Here's how you can verify your API keys are working:

**Option 1: Check via the health endpoint**

Start your backend and visit: http://localhost:8000/

You'll see output like:
```json
{
  "status": "healthy",
  "api_keys": {
    "openai": "configured",    // or "missing"
    "ebird": "configured",     // or "missing"
    "anthropic": "not set (optional)",
    "tavily": "not set (optional)"
  },
  ...
}
```

**Option 2: Test eBird key directly**

Run this in your terminal (replace with your actual key):
```bash
curl -s "https://api.ebird.org/v2/data/obs/US-CA/recent?maxResults=1" \
  -H "X-eBirdApiToken: YOUR_EBIRD_KEY_HERE"
```

If it returns JSON bird data, your eBird key works. If it returns an error, the key is invalid.

**Option 3: Test OpenAI key**
```bash
curl -s https://api.openai.com/v1/models \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer YOUR_OPENAI_KEY_HERE" | head -c 200
```

If it returns model data, your OpenAI key works.

**Make sure your `.env` file:**
1. Is located at `/home/ethan/Documents/overclockAccelerator/capstone/backend/.env`
2. Has the format:
```
EBIRD_API_KEY=abc123...
OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-...
```
(no quotes around values)

Would you like me to create a simple test script to verify the keys?

**To fix this:**

1. Get a free eBird API key from: https://ebird.org/api/keygen

Your eBird API key is now configured. Both `openai` and `ebird` show as `"configured"`.

The issue was that `docker-compose restart` doesn't reload the `.env` file - it just restarts the container with the same environment. You need `docker-compose up -d --force-recreate` to pick up new environment variables.

Your rare bird alerts and other eBird-powered features should work now. Try the "Get Rare Bird Alerts" button again on the Community page.

   - Cards below map for quick browsing

Fixed! The backend has reloaded with the new changes. 

The issue was that the image wasn't being sent to the AI model properly. I updated the `/api/identify/upload` endpoint to:

1. **Use GPT-4o Vision directly** - Sends the image as a base64-encoded data URL to OpenAI's vision model
2. **High detail mode** - Uses `"detail": "high"` for better image analysis
3. **Better prompting** - Includes structured instructions for identification

Try dragging and dropping a bird photo again - it should now analyze the image and identify the bird species with confidence scores, distinguishing features, and alternative possibilities.

_**User**_

How do I stop the docker container

---

_**Agent (model claude-4.5-opus-high-thinking, mode Agent)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The user wants to know how to stop the Docker containers. I'll provide them with the command.</details></think>

---

To stop the Docker containers, run:

```bash
cd /home/ethan/Documents/overclockAccelerator/capstone
docker-compose down
```

This stops and removes all the containers. Your data in PostgreSQL and Redis will be preserved in Docker volumes.

**Other useful commands:**

- **Stop without removing:** `docker-compose stop`
- **Stop and remove volumes (full reset):** `docker-compose down -v`
- **Restart:** `docker-compose restart`
- **Start again:** `docker-compose up -d`

Uses endpoints at `https://st-download.ebird.org/v1/` and requires an access key from https://ebird.org/st/request. Requires API keys tied to eBird accounts for most endpoints. Supports non-commercial use including scientific research, education, and open-source applications.<br/><br/>**eBird Data Downloads** [5] - Open data access includes:<br/>- eBird Basic Dataset (EBD) - Raw observations updated monthly<br/>- eBird Observational Dataset<br/>- Personal data downloads<br/><br/>**iNaturalist API** [4] - REST endpoints for reading and writing biodiversity observation data. Supports both read-only and authenticated requests with OAuth2 authentication. Data available in multiple formats (JSON, etc.).<br/><br/>## Terms and Access<br/><br/>All eBird APIs require authentication via API keys and are subject to terms of use [3]. The Cornell Lab of Ornithology reserves the right to modify or discontinue API versions at any time [3].<br/><br/>*Note: Results focused on established APIs rather than specific 2025-2026 releases or announcements.* |

Example endpoint: `https://www.xeno-canto.org/api/2/recordings?query=\{species\}`[1] Python and JavaScript client libraries are available for integration.[1][4]<br/><br/>## Macaulay Library (Cornell)<br/>The Macaulay Library at Cornell Lab of Ornithology is the world's largest scientific archive of wildlife recordings.[5] While primarily accessible through web-based search tools and downloadable guides rather than an API, it offers comprehensive bird sound resources. Their "Cornell Guide to Bird Sounds: United States and Canada" compilation covers 901 species with 4,959 curated audio files available for download.[3] Recordings can be searched by species, and the sounds are incorporated into tools like the Merlin Bird ID app and eBird.[3][5]<br/><br/>## Key Differences<br/>- **Xeno-Canto**: Free API with programmatic access to a large global database<br/>- **Macaulay Library**: Primarily download-based with curated, hand-selected recordings focused on North American birds; offers search tools but limited API access compared to Xeno-Canto |

[Understanding the Model Context Protocol (MCP): Forging the Future of Interconnected AI \| by Francisco Orcha \| Medium](https://medium.com/@ajicar/understanding-the-model-context-protocol-mcp-forging-the-future-of-interconnected-ai-c729adf041cf)<br/>3. [BirdStats  MCP](https://mcpcursor.com/server/birdstats-mcp)<br/>4. [Model Context Protocol](https://developers.openai.com/codex/mcp)<br/>5. [Model context protocol (MCP) - OpenAI Agents SDK](https://openai.github.io/openai-agents-python/mcp/)<br/><br/># MCP Model Context Protocol for Birds, Nature & Wildlife<br/><br/>## What is MCP?<br/><br/>The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open standardized protocol that connects AI models and language models to external tools, data sources, and applications.[2][5] It solves the "M×N problem" where integration complexity explodes as the number of AI models and external tools increases exponentially.[2] MCP acts like "a USB-C port for AI applications," providing a unified way to connect models to various resources.[5]<br/><br/>## Bird & Wildlife Applications<br/><br/>Several MCP servers have been developed specifically for bird watching and ecological research:<br/><br/>**BirdNet-Pi MCP Server**: A Python-based application that integrates bird detection data, offering features like filtering detections by date and species, generating statistics, analyzing daily activity patterns, and accessing audio recordings.[1] Use cases include monitoring bird populations and analyzing activity patterns over time.[1]<br/><br/>**BirdStats MCP**: Integrates BirdNET-Pi and eBird APIs to cross-reference bird detection data with observation records for ecological research and bird watching insights.[3] It allows natural language queries such as "My BirdNET heard a Swainson's Thrush - is that unusual?" and enables data-driven visualizations.[3]<br/><br/>## Key Features<br/><br/>These bird-focused MCP implementations provide:<br/>- Natural language interfaces for querying bird detection and observation data[3]<br/>- Statistical analysis and reporting capabilities[1]<br/>- Integration with multiple bird monitoring APIs and databases[3]<br/>- Visualization tools for bird activity patterns[3] |

| Web search results for query: iNaturalist API bird observations integration |  | Links:<br/>1. [API Reference<br/> ·  iNaturalist](https://www.inaturalist.org/pages/api+reference)<br/>2. [Access iNaturalist data through APIs](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/rinat/vignettes/rinat-intro.html)<br/>3. [Observations ¶](https://pyinaturalist.readthedocs.io/en/stable/modules/pyinaturalist.v1.observations.html)<br/>4. [iNaturalist API](https://api.inaturalist.org/v1/docs/)<br/>5. [Search code, repositories, users, issues, pull requests...](https://github.com/inaturalist/iNaturalistAPI)<br/><br/># iNaturalist API Bird Observations Integration<br/><br/>## API Options<br/><br/>iNaturalist provides two primary APIs for accessing observation data:[1]<br/><br/>1. **Faster Node.js API** at `api.inaturalist.org/v1/` - Offers more consistent response formats and faster performance[4]<br/>2. **Original Ruby on Rails API** - Has more functionality and supports more write operations, though slower[1]<br/><br/>## Key Features for Bird Observations<br/><br/>**Data Access:** Read-only endpoints don't require authentication, but authenticated requests are needed for unobscured coordinates or write operations.[1] The API returns data in JSON/JSONP and PNG formats.[4]<br/><br/>**Search Capabilities:** You can filter observations by:<br/>- Taxon name (species or taxonomic group)<br/>- Observation date<br/>- Record quality (research-grade data is recommended for reliability)<br/>- Geographic bounding boxes[2]<br/><br/>## Authentication<br/><br/>The Node API uses JSON Web Tokens (JWT) obtained through OAuth-authenticated requests to `https://www.inaturalist.org/users/api_token`. JWTs expire after 24 hours.[4] The original API supports OAuth2 with Authorization Code, Resource Owner Password Credentials, and PKCE flows.[1]<br/><br/>## Client Libraries<br/><br/>Several wrapper libraries simplify integration:<br/>- **rinat** (R package) - Primary function `get_inat_obs()` retrieves observations with filtering options[2]<br/>- **pyinaturalist** (Python) - Provides observation modules and controllers for accessing bird data[3]<br/><br/>**Rate Limiting:** API usage is throttled to 100 requests per minute (60 requested as a courtesy).[4] |

| Web search results for query: BirdNET bird sound identification API neural network |  | Links:<br/>1. [BirdNET-Analyzer Documentation — BirdNET-Analyzer  documentation](https://birdnet-team.github.io/BirdNET-Analyzer/)<br/>2. [About BirdNET](https://birdnet.cornell.edu/about/)<br/>3. [BirdNET Demo](https://birdnet.cornell.edu/api/)<br/>4. [BirdNET-Analyzer](https://birdnet.cornell.edu/analyzer/)<br/>5. [About BirdNET Live](https://birdnet-team.github.io/real-time-pwa/about/)<br/><br/># BirdNET: Bird Sound Identification with Neural Networks<br/><br/>BirdNET is a machine learning research platform that uses deep neural networks to identify bird species from audio recordings.[2] It's a collaboration between the K. Lisa Yang Center for Conservation Bioacoustics at Cornell Lab of Ornithology and Chemnitz University of Technology.[1][2]<br/><br/>## Neural Network Architecture<br/><br/>BirdNET uses a deep neural network with convolutional and residual layers.[2] The system converts audio windows into spectrogram features (specifically Mel Spectrograms for visual frequency representations) and feeds them into a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN).[2][5] The model outputs embeddings (compact numeric representations of sound) and per-species confidence scores.[2]<br/><br/>## API and Tools<br/><br/>BirdNET offers multiple interfaces for bird sound identification:[1]<br/><br/>- **BirdNET-Analyzer**: An open-source tool for large-scale audio analysis with GUI and command-line options, supporting batch processing of thousands of hours of audio[1][4]<br/>- **BirdNET Demo**: A web-based API that processes audio directly in your browser using TensorFlow.js, without uploading data to servers[3][5]<br/>- **BirdNET Live**: A Progressive Web App for real-time identification from microphone input[5]<br/>- **Python packages and R integration** for programmatic access[1]<br/><br/>## Recognition Workflow<br/><br/>The system captures audio, preprocesses it into 3-second windows, converts to spectrograms, runs neural network inference, applies confidence thresholds and geographic filters, and aggregates detections with species labels and timestamps.[2]<br/><br/>The models can recognize over 6,000 bird species worldwide and are trained on curated vocalizations with audio augmentation for robustness to background noise.[2] |

The app uses training data from millions of photos and sounds submitted to the Macaulay Library by birders worldwide. Experienced birders curate and annotate the photos and sounds to improve accuracy.<br/><br/>**Development:**[5]<br/>Photo ID was developed by researchers at Caltech and Cornell Tech, while Sound ID was created by the Macaulay Library team.<br/><br/>## Cornell APIs<br/><br/>The Cornell Lab of Ornithology maintains several public web service APIs for ornithology data, including eBird APIs documented through their Information Science API portal.[1] However, specific details about a dedicated bird migration tracker API were not found in these results. |

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
All done! Let me provide a summary of the changes I made to the user.</details></think>

---

I've implemented the Migration & Trends AI Agent. Here's what was added:

**Backend Changes:**

1. **New Migration Agent** (`backend/app/agents/migration.py`):
   - Expert in bird migration patterns, seasonal movements, and timing predictions
   - Provides migration forecasts, best time to see species, and trend analysis
   - Uses eBird, weather data, and web search tools

2. **New API Endpoints** in `main.py`:
   - `GET /api/migration/forecast` - Get 1-2 week migration forecast for a location
   - `GET /api/migration/best-time` - Get the best weeks to see a specific species
   - `GET /api/migration/species-info` - Get migration profile for a species (used by map popups)

3. **Agent Registration**:
   - Added to the team roster so the chat can delegate migration questions
   - Registered in the agent type enum and exports

**Frontend Changes:**

1. **Chat Integration**:
   - Added "Migration Trends" agent option in `ChatPage.tsx`
   - Added migration-related suggested prompts

2. **Home Page**:
   - Added new "Migration Trends" card with teal gradient

3. **Map Popup Enhancement** (`BirdMap.tsx`):
   - When clicking on a rare bird sighting, there's now an expandable "Migration & Timing Info" section
   - Clicking it fetches detailed migration data from the AI agent
   - Shows migration status, peak timing, current status, range, and notable behaviors
   - Results are cached to avoid repeated API calls

**To test the changes**, rebuild your Docker containers:

```bash
docker-compose down
docker-compose build backend
docker-compose up -d
```

Then try:
- Chat with the migration agent: "When do warblers arrive in my area?"
- Get a forecast: "What birds are migrating through right now?"
- Click on a rare bird marker on the map and expand "Migration & Timing Info"

Done! I've added the Life List Coach agent. Here's what was created:

**New Agent (`backend/app/agents/lifelist.py`):**
- Analyzes birding goals and suggests realistic "next target" species
- Considers location, season, skill level, and recent sightings
- Provides difficulty ratings (Easy/Moderate/Challenging)
- Gives specific locations, timing, and pro tips for each target
- Identifies gaps in life lists and "low-hanging fruit"

**New API Endpoints:**
- `GET /api/lifelist/targets` - Get suggested target species for your location
- `GET /api/lifelist/analyze` - Analyze your life list progress and get strategy
- `GET /api/lifelist/seasonal-targets` - Get time-sensitive "don't miss" species

**Chat Integration:**
- Added to the team roster so you can ask things like:
  - "What bird should I try to find next?"
  - "What are some easy birds I might be missing?"
  - "I have 150 species - what should I target next?"
  - "What's migrating through that I need to see before it leaves?"

**Frontend Updates:**
- Added `lifelist` agent type
- Updated suggested prompts with life list questions
- Updated stats to show "8 AI Agents"

To test, rebuild Docker and try asking in the chat: "What birds should I try to find near Cleveland, Ohio this month?"

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
All done. Let me provide a summary for the user.</details></think>

---

Done! I've added an autocomplete component for bird species. Here's what I created:

**New Component (`frontend/src/components/BirdAutocomplete.tsx`):**
- Contains 400+ common North American bird species
- Filters as you type with smart matching:
  - Birds that **start with** your input appear first
  - Birds that **contain** your input appear after
- Shows up to 10 suggestions at a time
- Keyboard navigation support (Arrow keys, Enter, Escape)
- Highlights matching text in suggestions
- Shows a bird emoji next to each suggestion
- Accessible with proper ARIA attributes

**Features:**
- Type "ro" → suggests "Rock Pigeon", "Robin" (American Robin), "Rose-breasted Grosbeak", etc.
- Type "war" → suggests all warblers
- Type "hum" → suggests all hummingbirds
- If no match is found, you can still enter the name manually

**Updated Journal Page:**
- Replaced the plain text input with the new autocomplete component
- Works exactly the same but now helps users find and spell bird names correctly

The component is reusable, so it can be added to other forms in the app if needed (like the Target Species field on the Locations page).
